Sir Wilfrid Robarts.Action: Tells his nurse to stop talking and jokes about regretting coming out of a coma due to her chatty nature.
Slaps nurse's hand when she tries to tuck him in more carefully.
Handles his ill health with gruff humor and maintains a sharp tongue despite weakness.
Refuses to let nurse Miss Plimsoll overly coddle him, asserting control over his comfort (slaps her hand away).
Shows irritability and somewhat dismissive attitude toward his nurse's concern (tells her to 'roll up your mouth'), which could undermine cooperation.
Dismisses Miss Plimsoll's gentle reminder with 'Shut up!' and ignores her offered hand.
Ignores the reception line-up formed by his employees and takes the flowers from Miss McHugh without acknowledgment.
Starts briskly up stone steps shortly after a heart attack, showing physical determination and confidence.
Dismisses Miss Plimsoll's gentle reminder about his heart condition with a sharp 'shut up!'
Ignores the reception line-up and passes through purposefully, demonstrating focus and authority.
Whisks flowers from Miss McHugh's hand without acknowledgment, showing possible brusqueness.
Whisks the flowers from Miss McHugh's hand while passing, ignoring the reception line-up.
Interrupts Miss McHugh, dismissing the poem as sentimental and telling her to recite it after office hours.
Notices Miss O'Brien sobbing and asks what is the matter with her.
Shoves flowers at Miss Plimsoll after she teases him, calling her 'blabbermouth!'
Uses a sweeping gesture with his cane to dismiss sentimentality and threatens to go back to hospital if it continues.
Ignores the reception line-up and proceeds directly toward his office with confident authority.
Dismisses a welcoming poem abruptly, prioritizing work over sentimental interruptions.
Reacting sharply to emotional displays, such as telling Miss O'Brien that showing sentimentality will cause him to return to hospital.
Uses humor and mild rebuke in a social context (calling Miss Plimsoll a 'Blabbermouth!'), displaying social savvy and confidence.
Demonstrates a keen awareness of his surroundings and own office’s state, suggesting reflective and self-aware qualities.
Responds with gratitude when Carter lights a candle for him, showing appreciation for loyal care.
Reminisces fondly about his long relationship with Carter, indicating a respectful and friendly bond.
Shows sharp irritation about the moth balls in which his wig was stored, revealing a moment of bluntness but motivated by eagerness to practice again.
Expresses relief on hearing about upcoming briefs and shows wistfulness, indicating sincerity and emotional openness.
Resignedly accepts his medical restrictions and mocks his own condition with humor.
Jokingly threatens Miss Plimsoll with justifiable homicide and striking her with a cane, but in a playful manner.
Displays sarcasm and irritation toward Miss Plimsoll’s care and baby talk.
Expresses frustration and resignation about his medical restrictions preventing him from taking on criminal cases.
Uses humor and role-play to cope with his situation, demonstrating wit and mental agility despite physical limitations.
Threatens a nurse semi-jokingly, showing irritability but no actual loss of control or professionalism.
Shows playful resistance and humor when confronted about smuggling cigars, tries to negotiate for one after meals.
Threatens Miss Plimsoll with his cane, though likely in jest.
Displays stubbornness and pride by refusing help and asserting independence (rejects being helped on lift), but ultimately cooperates.
Enjoys the stairlift playfully, joking with Carter and Miss Plimsoll, sharing a lighthearted moment.
Uses the stairlift himself, shows confidence and humor in learning its controls despite health issues.
Takes the stairlift up and down on his own before mastering it.
Jokes familiarly with Mayhew about his health and younger men, showing a playful and engaging demeanor.
Responds curtly and abruptly to Miss Plimsoll by telling her to 'Shut up!'
Shows interest and polite engagement by greeting Mr. Vole and looking at him with interest despite his own convalescing state.
Stops the inclinato to call back Mayhew and offers personal help despite having declined to take the brief, indicating genuine concern for an old friend.
Invites Mayhew into his office for a private word of advice, showing a willingness to help beyond formal obligations.
Closes the door in Miss Plimsoll’s face, prioritizing privacy over politeness in the moment.
Interrupts his departure to offer urgent help to an old friend despite previously deciding not to take the brief, showing flexibility and prioritization of important matters.
Quickly isolates conversation with Mayhew alone in his office to provide confidential advice, demonstrating discretion and tactical thinking.
Allows Miss Plimsoll to start the next task without him, managing his time effectively under pressure.
Circles Mayhew attentively despite distracted by cigars, asks to be lit a cigar politely.
Self-absorbed focus on cigars and matches rather than fully listening to case details.
Prevents Mayhew from leaving to get matches, implying trust and reliance on each other’s abilities in case preparation.
Circles Mayhew attentively, seeks details of the case from him.
Focuses distractedly on the cigars instead of the case details Mayhew is relating.
Requests a cigar to help think better about the case.
Searches frantically for matches to light the cigar, indicating some distraction or disorganization.
Stops Mayhew from leaving to get matches because he knows it requires subtlety and care, implying strategic thinking.
Absorbed in his cigar, calmly handles ash without concern for appearances, speaks with slight sharpness when clarifying legal procedures to Vole.
Interrupts Vole sharply to clarify the nature of police caution, showing focus on precision rather than warmth.
Acknowledges ethical and medical limitations by declining the case despite its importance and suggests a competent colleague instead.
Demonstrates clear communication and professionalism in handling a difficult situation involving Mr. Vole's anxieties.
Shoves his cigar into Vole's hand casually and opens door for him, showing informal friendliness.
Slams the door in Miss Plimsoll's face after a sarcastic reply to her emotional complaint.
Speaks positively about Brogan-Moore, praising his training under him, indicating professional support and pride.
Reassures Vole not to worry about legal costs despite Vole's financial troubles, indicating kindness and tolerance.
Delegates tasks promptly and confidently by asking for Brogan-Moore to be sent to his office immediately.
Interacts with subordinates and associates with a confident and somewhat dismissive manner (slams door in Miss Plimsoll's face).
Shows self-assurance and relaxed control by taking the cigar back from Vole and calmly seating himself behind the desk.
Reassures client boldly about handling financial difficulties with humorous confidence ('we'll get a fourth lawyer to sue you').
Listens attentively to Vole's account and asks questions to understand his background.
Drops ashes in the drawer while commenting 'Very annoying.' in a detached manner.
Shows a penetrating glance at Vole that makes him uncomfortable, indicating a probing and potentially intimidating demeanor.
Asks pointed, clarifying questions to understand witness background and details (e.g., asking about awkwardness, egg-beater invention)
Nonchalantly drops ashes in drawer while questioning, seeming slightly distracted or indifferent
Inquires methodically about how Vole met Mrs. French, showing attention to detail and strategic questioning.
Does not intervene or comment during Vole and Mrs. French's interaction about hats, demonstrating restraint and focus on gathering information rather than distraction.
Listens attentively to Vole's account with interest and mild humor.

Engages with Vole in conversation about Mrs. French, showing interest in others' circumstances.
Flicks ashes into the drawer while telling Mayhew not to smoke, showing some brusqueness.
Engages calmly in office discussion, attentively clarifies details about Mrs. French and her background, showing awareness and control.
Shows minor disregard for decorum by flicking ashes in drawer during conversation.
Invites others to have a fire and makes the room feel welcoming.
Encourages use of good silver and china for serving tea, showing hospitable behavior.
Comforts Mrs. French by downplaying Janet’s sarcasm and maintaining a pleasant atmosphere.
Assures that the victim has been moved promptly, stating it would be unfeeling, unlawful and unsanitary not to do so, and personally empties ashes from the drawer into the street.
Interrupts Vole abruptly with a pointed question about money from Mrs. French, showing suspicion rather than warmth or friendliness.
Listens without looking at Vole and continues polishing his monocle during Vole's statement, suggesting detachment or impatience.
Questions Vole sharply about his motives and honesty; uses sharp skeptical probing.
Engages directly with Vole's statements, pressing him to clarify and explain personal and sensitive matters.
Reassures Mr. Vole sincerely that he believes him despite difficult circumstances.
Engages gently with Mr. Vole, asking detailed questions about his whereabouts and credibility.
Slightly cynical remark about the unreliability of a devoted wife's testimony.
Calmly assesses the emotional state of the accused and maintains composure, showing confidence in handling a tense situation.
Asks detailed, precise questions about the timeline and witness credibility, indicating thoroughness and intelligence.
Acknowledges the weakness in the accused's alibi and challenges its credibility tactfully.
Uses irony and subtle humor (e.g., 'Blood is thicker than evidence') to disarm and reveal flaws in testimony, demonstrating skillful courtroom strategy.
Acknowledges the problematic impact of the inheritance on Vole's case, speaks soberly and realistically about the difficulties.

Calmly assesses the implications of the inheritance on the case and acknowledges the strength of the prosecution's motive argument.
Maintains composure when Vole reacts emotionally and seems to be careful in his approach rather than rushing to defend or contradict.
Appears contemplative and observant, watching the street and a police car arriving, indicating situational awareness.
Welcomes the Chief Inspector into his office and closes the door politely, showing respect and tolerance towards the police.
Makes a lighthearted joke about Leonard Vole possibly being armed with an egg-beater, easing tension with humor.
Reassures Leonard Vole that there is no disgrace in being arrested, citing esteemed people who have stood in the dock, offering comfort and tolerance.
Does not intervene when Leonard Vole seems worried about his wife being informed of the arrest, allowing Brogan-Moore to handle it.

Makes a light-hearted comment about Mr. Vole's behavior, showing cordiality and wit.
Discusses the legal challenge with a tone of admiration and professional respect.
Responds humorously to Miss Plimsoll's ultimatum, showing a playful, warm side.
Jokes about giving Miss Plimsoll two months' pay and kicking her down the stairs; takes Carter's arm casually for support.
Refuses to deal with emotional wives, stating he is in no condition to cope.

Handles interactions with calm professionalism, welcoming Christine Vole politely.
Acknowledges his physical limits and decides to rest when advised, showing self-awareness.
Gives detailed and practical instructions on handling Mrs. Vole's possible emotional reaction, indicating foresight and preparation.
Responds to blackmail comment with humor and calm, maintaining composure under pressure.

Gently informs Christine Vole of her husband's arrest with a sober, calm demeanor and acknowledges her fortitude.
Expresses regret for not personally defending Leonard due to health reasons but maintains professionalism.
Glares at the closed door after Christine's departure, showing inner frustration or concern, but does not lash out.
Politely and clearly explains the legal situation and next steps to Christine Vole, demonstrating knowledge of legal procedure.
Delegates the defense to Mr. Brogan-Moore due to health issues, showing realistic self-assessment and practical delegation.

Dismisses Miss Plimsoll's sympathetic and preliminary remarks lightly (tells her to 'shut up' jokingly).

Enters quietly and gestures to Brogan-Moore to continue interview, then moves to observe Mrs. Vole attentively.

Asks relevant background questions to gather more information and understand context.

Is notably absent at the start of the trial scene where everyone else is present, suggesting a delay or different timing which may point to either strategic timing or a negative sign if interpreted as tardiness.
Absent at the start of the trial due to slight incapacitation but supported by colleagues.

Acknowledged by defense and prosecution as a learned and stimulating presence, implying a respected professional reputation.

Despite serious medical condition and doctors' insistence, insists on going to courtroom and continuing the trial.
